item.title: Pope Leo's Lebanon visit sparks frustration as he'll skip the most battered region
item.description: Pope Leo visits war-torn Lebanon but some in the country with the biggest percentage of Christians in the region are upset he's skipping the most battered part.

item.title: Pope Leo prays for unity at historic Nicaea site
item.description: On the second day of his inaugural overseas trip, Pope Leo XIV visited the ancient site of the First Council of Nicaea, in Turkey, urging Christians — and all faiths — to reject the use of religion to justify violence.
item.content:encoded:
On the second day of his inaugural overseas trip, Pope Leo XIV visited the ancient site of the First Council of Nicaea, in Turkey, urging Christians — and all faiths — to reject the use of religion to justify violence.

(Image credit: Chris McGrath)
item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock

item.title: Pope Leo is traveling to Turkey and Lebanon on the first foreign trip of his papacy
item.description: This Thanksgiving, Pope Leo is making his first overseas trip as pontiff. He started in Turkey, where he called for tolerance between different peoples and religions.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV to visit Turkey and Lebanon on first foreign trip
item.description: Pope Leo XIV is embarking on his first foreign trip, a pilgrimage to Turkey and Lebanon, amid Mideast tensions and the media glare that will document history's first American pope on the road.

item.title: Utah Gov. Cox appealed for civility after Charlie Kirk's murder. Did America listen?
item.description: After right-wing activist Charlie Kirk was assassinated, Utah Gov. Spencer Cox called for civility. NPR's Steve Inskeep spoke with him at a meeting of the Western Governors' Association.

item.title: More than 300 children were abducted in an attack on a Catholic school in Nigeria
item.description: A total of 303 schoolchildren and 12 teachers were abducted by gunmen during an attack on St. Mary's School, a Catholic institution in north-central Nigeria's Niger state, the Christian Association of Nigeria said.

item.title: As more Catholic churches close, Philadelphia is trying something new
item.description: The Catholic Church is facing aging congregations, fewer priests and financial strain. In many places, this has meant closing parishes. But in Philadelphia, they're trying something different.
